D15/2/1
Second Expert Joint Statement between Olga Razzhivina and Philip Seymour 27th May 2022 
1. Introduction 
1.1 This is the  Second Joint Statement of: 
(i) Olga Razzhivina ("Ms Razzhivina") of Oriel Consult Limited; and 
(ii) Philip Seymour ("Mr Seymour") of the International Bureau of Aviation Group Limited (together, the "Experts"). 
1.2 It is an updated version of a Joint Statement produced on 9 March 2022 with additional text shown in green. 
The Experts' reports 
1.3 Ms Razzhivina prepared a report dated 24 November 2021 ("OR1"). Mr Seymour prepared a report dated 24 January 2022 ("PS1"). 
1.4 In these reports the Experts were instructed to provide their opinion on the value of certain aircraft. Ms Razzhivina valued five aircraft. Mr 
Seymour valued those aircraft and an additional four. 
1.5 Ms Razzhivina was subsequently instructed to value three of the four additional aircraft Mr Seymour had valued, and provided her second 
aircraft report addressing the value of three of them dated 29 April 2022 ("OR2"). 
1.6 Save where expressly defined herein, the Experts use the same defined terms in this joint statement as in their reports. 
Meetings of the Experts since their reports 
1.7 On 17 February 2022, the Experts met by video call to discuss on a without prejudice basis matters related to their original instructions. 
1.8 On 12 May 2022, the Experts met by video call to discuss on a without prejudice basis matters related to their instructions in respect of the 
three aircraft valued in OR2. 
Structure of this joint statement 
1.9 Section 2 contains a summary of the Experts' respective instructions. 
1.10 Section 3 contains a summary of the Experts' respective assessments. 
1.11 Sections 4 to 8 contain a summary of the matters that are agreed and not agreed between the Experts in respect of: 
(i) overall conclusions; 
(ii) effect on valuation of differences in the Experts' respective instructions; 
(iii) valuation methodology; 
(iv) individual aircraft valuations; and 
(v) the reliability of the Veritas 2016 Valuation Reports. 
2/36 Second Expert Joint Statement between Olga Razzhivina and Philip Seymour 
 27th May 2022

2.3 Ms Razzhivina has been was originally instructed to provide her opinion on the market value of the five aircraft (the "Aircraft") that the First 
Defendant relies on in his Re-Re-Amended Defence ("D1 RRAD") and "Schedule 2" to D1 RRAD. The Aircraft are: 
(1) Airbus A321-200 MSN 2462 (the "Airbus"); 
(2) Boeing 737-300, MSN 28659 (the "Boeing 737"); 
(3) Boeing 767-300ER, MSN 25533 (the "Boeing 767 533"); 
(4) Boeing 767-300ER, MSN 25536 (the "Boeing 767 536"); and 
(5) Embraer ERJ-145LR MSN 145-250 (the "Embraer"). 
2.4 Mr Seymour nas been was instructed to provide his opinion on the market value of the Aircraft, plus an additional four aircraft (the "Additional 
Four Aircraft"), which Ms Olga Razzhivina has had not been instructed to value (PS1/2.1). The Additional Four Aircraft are: 
(1) Airbus A321-200, MSN 2682; 
(2) Boeing 767-300ER, MSN 25280; 
(3) Embraer ERJ-145EP, MSN 145-290; and 
(4) Embraer ERJ-145EP, MSN 145-394.

4/36 2. Summary of instructions 
 The Experts set out their respective instructions at: 
 
(1) OR1: ¶¶22 to 24 and Exhibit OR3 , and OR2: ¶¶ 9 to 11 and Exhibit OR5 ; and  
(2) PS1: ¶¶2.1 to 2.4.  
 The Experts identify the main similarities and differences in their instructions below.  
Subject of assessment 
 Ms Razzhivina has been was originally instructed to provide her opinion on the market value of the five aircraft (the " Aircraft") that the First 
Defendant relies on in his Re-Re-Amended Defence (“ D1 RRAD ”) and “Schedule 2 ” to D1 RRAD.  The Aircraft are: 
 
(1) Airbus A321-200 MSN 2462 (the “ Airbus”); 
(2) Boeing 737-300, MSN 28659 (the “ Boeing 737 ”); 
(3) Boeing 767-300ER, MSN 25533 (the “ Boeing 767 533 ”);  
(4) Boeing 767-300ER, MSN 25536 (the “ Boeing 767 536 ”); and 
(5) Embraer ERJ-145LR MSN 145-250 (the “ Embraer ”). 
 
 Mr Seymour has been was  instructed to provide his opinion on the market value of the Aircraft, plus an additional four aircraft (the " Additional 
Four Aircraft "), which Ms Olga Razzhivina has had not been instructed to value (PS1/2.1).  The Additional Four Aircraft are: 
 
(1) Airbus A321-200, MSN 2682; 
(2) Boeing 767-300ER, MSN 25280; 
(3) Embraer ERJ-145EP, MSN 145-290; and 
(4) Embraer ERJ-145EP, MSN 145-394.

2.5 Ms Razzhivina has been further instructed to provide her opinion on the market value of three of the Additional Four Aircraft. Those instruction: 
are at OR2 ¶¶ 9 to 11 and Exhibits OR5. The three aircraft are: 
(1) Airbus A321-200, MSN 2682 ("Additional Airbus"); 
(2) Embraer ERJ-145EP, MSN 145-290 ("Additional Embraer 290"); and 
(3) Embraer ERJ-145EP, MSN 145-394 ("Additional Embraer 394"). 
2.6 In respect of the fourth aircraft, the Boeing 767-300ER, MSN 25280 ("Additional Boeing 767"), Ms Razzhivina was instructed that the Bank 
accepts Mr Seymour's valuation of US$ 5,990,000 accordingly, she was not instructed to value it in OR2. 
2.7 Ms Olga Razzhivina has been instructed to comment on contemporaneous third party valuations of the Aircraft (OR1/21 and Appendix D). Mr 
Seymour was not specifically instructed to comment on contemporaneous third party valuations but since they were disclosed and opined upon 
by Ms Razzhivina, Mr Seymour thought it useful for the Court, since it is within his area of expertise, to provide commentary in this regard. 
2.8 Ms Razzhivina has been instructed to value the Aircraft under the 'market value' standard defined in the 2013 edition of the International 
Valuation Standards (OR1/23).

4.7 Applying a 
discount to the 
Airbus' value 
because of 
damage Significant damage to aircraft creates a stigma of 
damage which will result in a discount to the value, 
typically expressed in percentage to the value. 
Regardless of the quality of repairs, such discount 
applies. Ms Razzhivina quantifies the minimum 
discount at 10% of the Retrospective Adjusted 
Market Value (OR1/125-127). 
The 8 influencing factors stated by Mr Seymour are 
viewed by Ms Razzhivina to be in addition to the 
10% discount she assesses. Damage to aircraft creates a stigma of damage which 
may result into a discount to the value. While the fact 
of damage may create a discount to the value of an 
aircraft it cannot be quantified without knowing the 
details of the repairs and their quality. PS assesses 
each aircraft damage a per a "diminution in value" 
template which considers 8 influencing factors: the 
nature of the damage; area damaged; certification 
status; airworthiness limitations; OEM participatio

7.8 Treatment of 6-
year and 12-
year check for 
the purpose of 
maintenance 
adjustment The 6-year check is superseded by the 12-year 
check and should not be adjusted for separately 
(OR1/92-96). 
 
If the 6-year and 12-year checks were to be 
adjusted for separately (which Ms Razzhivina does 
not consider to be correct), the cost of the 12-check 
has to be adjusted to reflect exclusion of the 6-year 
check tasks.  Using Mr Seymour’s costs the 
adjustment is as follows: $1,200,000 - $800,000 = 
$400,000 (PS1/10.12).  The resulting adjustment for 
the 12-year check should be: $400,000/144*(144/2-
15) = $158,333. The 6-year and 12-year checks are adjusted for 
individually (PS1/10.12) Normally, PS would agree 
that the 6 and 12 year checks would be coincident, 
that is the 12 year should encompass the 6 year 
tasks. In this case PS  saw that the aircraft  (delivered 
in 2005) had a 6 year check in 2011 (as would be 
expected) but had a 12 year prematurely in 2015 (at 
only 10 years old) hence PS decided to split the 
valuation of each check. It creates a difference in the 
order of 300KUSD increase to PS’s valuation if he 
combines the two checks. Without knowing exactly 
which of the check work cards were accomplished or 
deferred it makes the detailed analysis impossible to 
assess. Whilst PS agrees that normally the 6 and 12 
year checks would be combined, in this case believes 
the separation is valid.

7.9 Applying a 
discount to the 
Airbus' value 
because of 
damage Significant damage to aircraft creates a stigma of 
damage which will result into a discount to the 
value, typically expressed in percentage to the 
value. Regardless of the quality of repairs, such 
discount applies. Ms Razzhivina quantifies the 
minimum discount at 10% of the Retrospective 
Adjusted Market Value (OR1/125-127). 
The 8 influencing factors stated by Mr Seymour are 
viewed by Ms Razzhivina to be in addition to the 
10% discount she assesses. Significant damage to aircraft creates a stigma of 
damage which may result into a discount to the value. 
While the fact of damage may create a discount to the 
value of an aircraft it cannot be quantified without

and warranty applied. Therefore PS was unable to
